node.name: Caused by the death of the most massive stars
node.info: By massive, we mean stars that are several times more massive than our own sun. Our sun is too small to explode as a supernova. These stars die because there is a change at the core. This change can occur in two ways. The first results in a type 1, when a white dwarf accumulates matter from another star causing nuclear fusion to occur. This releases energy and results in an explosion. The second is a type 2, when a massive star runs out of nuclear fuel causing the star’s core to collapse and an explosion to occur.

node.name: Observed as coloured starlight
node.info: This is called a supernova remnant. It occurs when the star’s shell collides with the gas in space.

node.name: Tools for the creation of our world
node.info: 1 also tell us that we live in an expanding universe. They act as lanterns to indicate cosmic distances, eg. distance to the next galaxy.

node.name: Observed by using robotic telescope to compare pictures of many galaxies on different nights
